qas.question: What is the liturgical language of Judaism?
What is also termed lason ha-kodesh, "the holy tongue?"
What are the Hebrew scriptures called?
What are the two languages of the Babylonian Talmud?
What is a closely related tongue to Hebrew?
What language did the Jews never speak?
How many Jews spoke Greek before the 3rd century BCE?
What language was the Babylonian Talmud not written in?
What language did the Jews of Israel not use at that time?

context: <a0_0><a1_0>Hebrew<a1_0/><a0_0/> is the liturgical language of Judaism (termed <b5_0>lashon ha-kodesh<b5_0/>, "the holy tongue"), the language in which most of the Hebrew scriptures (<a2_0>Tanakh<a2_0/>) were composed, and the daily speech of the Jewish people for centuries. By the 5th century BCE, <a4_0><b6_0>Aramaic<b6_0/><a4_0/>, a closely related tongue, joined Hebrew as the spoken language in Judea. By the 3rd century BCE, <b7_0>some<b7_0/> Jews of the diaspora were speaking <b8_0>Greek<b8_0/>. Others, such as in the Jewish communities of Babylonia, were speaking <a3_0>Hebrew and <b9_0>Aramaic<b9_0/><a3_0/>, the languages of the Babylonian Talmud. These languages were also used by the Jews of Israel at that time.[citation needed]
